user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_strx_to_uint64_n_:
```c
size_t
MHD_strx_to_uint64_n_ (const char *str,
                       size_t maxlen,
                       uint64_t *out_val)
{
  size_t i;
  uint64_t res;
  int digit;
  if (! str || ! out_val)
    return 0;

  res = 0;
  i = 0;
  while (i < maxlen && (digit = toxdigitvalue (str[i])) >= 0)
  {
    if ( (res > (UINT64_MAX / 16)) ||
         ((res == (UINT64_MAX / 16)) &&
          ( (uint64_t) digit > (UINT64_MAX % 16)) ) )
      return 0;

    res *= 16;
    res += (unsigned int) digit;
    i++;
  }

  if (i)
    *out_val = res;
  return i;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
while (i < maxlen && (digit = toxdigitvalue (str[i])) >= 0)
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 2.1 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation. The while-condition uses the short-circuit && operator so both operands are potentially reachable; the call to toxdigitvalue(str[i]) is evaluated only when i < maxlen, which is intended to avoid out-of-bounds access. There is no code that can never be executed at compile/run time. (An example that WOULD violate Rule 2.1: replacing the condition with a constant false first operand, e.g. while (0 && (digit = toxdigitvalue(str[i])) >= 0) — the assignment and call would then be unreachable.)
